Category: NONINFECTIOUS OR ABIOTIC DISEASES AND DAMAGE

Category: NONINFECTIOUS OR ABIOTIC DISEASES AND DAMAGE

Genetic connection; particulate matter lodged

grow on

Category: NONINFECTIOUS OR ABIOTIC DISEASES AND DAMAGE
Pathogen:
Accumulation of sugars and other photosynthetic
products

genusBigeminivirus, Euphorbia mosaic virus(EuMV)
Poinsettia mosaic virus (possible tymovirus) (PnMV)
Air pollutant injury from either chlorides (> 0.5 ppm), nitrogen dioxide (>2-3 ppm) or sulfur dioxide (>0.5 ppm)
Physiological disorder favored by high humidity, heavy watering and high (ammoniacal) fertility rates in the last 4 weeks of production

Nitrogen deficiency producing a general foliar yellowing
Molybdenum deficiency affecting mature young leaves andproducing upward leaf roll
Sulfur deficiency causing young leaf yellowing
Zinc deficiency producing general yellowing and stunting ofnew leaves
Response to low light conditions, dryness and/or high temperatures at the end of the production cycle
Ethylene toxicity (< 1 ppm) or low temperature chilling

Magnesium deficiency, initiating on older leaves
Manganese deficiency, initiating on young mature leaves
Ammonium toxicity produces V-shaped chlorotic bandsstarting at the leaf tip and accompanied by downward leafcupping
High internal turgor pressure associated with certain cultivars, high humidity, high moisture availability, low temperatures and/or mechanical abrasion

Peroxyacetyl nitrate (PAN) injury to the lower epidermis
(>0.2 ppm)

Potassium deficiency
Fluoride toxicity on tips and margins of young leaves and bracts(0.4 ppm in water)
Lithium toxicity on older leaves (2 ppm)

The name"Fusarium graminearumSchwabe" now has the original broad sense (sensu lato) and a new narrow sense(sensu stricto). The term"Fusarium graminearumspecies complex" can also beused to indicate the broad sense. Authors should make clear whether they areusingsensu latoorsensu stricto. The members of theFusarium graminearumspecies complex are as follows:Fusarium acaciae-mearnsiiO'Donnell, T. Aoki, Kistler, & GeiserFusarium aethiopicumO'Donnell, Aberra, Kistler, & T.
